Biography

Robert Borden is Notable.

Robert Borden was a lawyer and politician, born 26 June 1854 in Grand Pré, Nova Scotia, first child of Andrew Borden and Eunice Laird. He married Laura Bond 25 September 1889 in Halifax; they had no children. He died 10 June 1937 in Ottawa.

Robert Borden était un avocat et homme politique, né le 26 juin 1854 à Grand-Pré, Nouvelle-Écosse, premier enfant d’Andrew Borden et Eunice Laird; le 25 septembre 1889, il épousa à Halifax Laura Bond et ils n’eurent pas d’enfants; décédé le 10 juin 1937 à Ottawa.[1]

At the time of the 1871 Canada Census, Andrew, Eunice Jane, Thomas A., Robert L., William J., Julia H., and Henry C. Borden were listed as living in Lower Horton, Nova Scotia, along with a servant and a woman listed as Julia "Leard", but was probably Eunice's mother, Julia Laird[2].

Robert married Laura Bond in Halifax, Nova Scotia, on September 25, 1889.[3][4] On their marriage registration, Robert's occupation was listed as "Barrister". They had no children.

Sir Robert Laird Borden (Conservative Party of Canada-Unionist) was Canada's Prime Minister from October 10, 1911, to October 12, 1917, and again from October 12, 1917, to July 10, 1920.

He was first elected to the House of Commons in 1896 and before that he practised law.

Borden was Prime Minister during World War I.

Borden imposed the War Measures Act in 1914.

insisted that Canada be allowed more input in planning Allied actions.

proposed conscription so there would be adequate reinforcements.

conscription divided Canada and Borden's Cabinet. Quebec refused to support it.

a Union Party, a coalition of Liberals and Conservatives, was formed and won the 1917 election but Quebec had no representation in Cabinet.

many Canadians of foreign ethinicity, in particular those with German ancestry, were denied the right to vote under the War Measures Act.

in 1917 Borden enacted the Income Tax Act, the Military Service Act, and the Wartime Elections Act.

In 1918 women were given the right to vote.

in 1920 Borden resigned as Prime Minister due to health issues.

After politics:

Appointed Chancellor of Queen's University, Kingston, Ontario, 1924-1930.

Appointed President of Crown Life Insurance, 1928.

Appointed President of Barclay's Band (Canada), 1929.

Appointed President of the Canadian Historical Association, 1930.[5]

Robert died in Ottawa on June 10, 1937, and was buried at Beechwood Cemetery, Ottawa, Ontario.[6]
